passages.text: Latin America | Diario
Diario | Latin America
Brazil Healthcare, Brazil Retail, C&A, Chile, Hapvida, ILC, Mexico buybacks, Rede D'Or

Brazil Healthcare | Watch the video | Why Rede D'Or over Hapvida. We recently initiated coverage on Brazilian Healthcare with Rede D'Or (Buy) and Hapvida (Hold). Rede D'Or has predictable growth, stable cash flows, and strong customer captivity. Hapvida has an advantageous business model but faces growth challenges and capital constraints. Link

ILC (Buy) | Earnings call highlights. Banco Internacional provisions increased in the quarter even though NPLs were down from \(3.1\%\) to \(2.8\%\) due to a few specific commercial clients. The higher cost of risk does not reflect a deterioration in the overall loan portfolio, which remains sound and within historical norms. Banco Internacional net income was down \(18\%\) to \(\) 9.8bn\(due to higher provisions, while all other segments contributed positively to earnings in 2Q25\) (\) 74.5bn in 2Q25 as against \(\) 6.2bn\(net losses in 2Q24). Banco Internacional issued Chile's first AT1 bond and completed two capital increases totaling\) \ \(28.5bn\) . Red Salud signed a binding agreement to acquire Nuevo Sanatorio Alemán. Sanatorio Alemán Clinic in Concepción is the largest private clinic outside of Santiago and the oldest in the country. It has more than 180 beds.

Mexico buybacks | Gruma, Femsa, AMX, Walnex and Bimbo amongst the most active buybacks. Telesites (3.7% of share capital), Gruma (3.1%), Vesta (1.8%), Nemak (1.3% local), Femsa (1.1%) and AMX (1.1%) were the Mexican companies mostly active with buybacks YTD, with Gruma, Nemak, Inbursa, Walnex and Bimbo among the most active in the last month. We expect more to come in 2025 at AMX, Gruma, Laureate Education and Femsa.

C&A (Buy) | \*Reminder\* Today | Fireside Chat with C&A CFO. We are hosting a virtual group meeting with Laurence Gomes (CFO) today, Thursday, 28 August, 10.00am EST | 11.00am BRT | 15.00pm BST. C&A began operating in Brazil in 1976 and currently has more than 300 stores in 125 cities across the country. C&A has been consistently gaining share, leading 'value for money' consumer perceptions, leveraging on superior data analytics and dynamic pricing. Registration here

Brazil Retail | H&M opens in Brazil. H&M opened its first physical store in Brazil and launched online operations, and plans to open four stores in Sao Paulo state over the coming months according to H&M Brazil's country manager, in an interview with Reuters. The first Brazilian store focuses on women's fashion while the second will offer a wider assortment of products including women's, men's and children's clothing, accessories and shoes. H&M is producing shoes, beachwear and jeans in Brazil and importing the other products from different markets, including Iga, Bangladesh and Portugal. H&M plans to open 80 new stores globally while closing 200 stores this year in mature markets. H&M expects Brazil to become its largest market in Latin America and a key growth driver worldwide. H&M took 13 years to reach 67 stores in Mexico. Pricing is expected to be materially lower than Zara in the market but still above local department stores such as Renner and C&A.

Chile Political & Economic Outlook | Turning Right At Next Elections? On September 16th at 9am ET/2pm UK, we will host an expert call with economist Mr Francisco Matte to discuss Chile's political and economic outlook, ahead of the upcoming presidential elections. Mr Francisco Matte is a Strategic Advisor at The World Bank, Lecturer at the Pontificia Universidade Católica de Chile, and former Chief of Staff to the Minister of Finance. Register here.

We recently initiated coverage on Brazilian Healthcare with Rede D'Or (BUY) and Hapvida (HOLD). Rede D'Or has predictable growth, stable cash flows, and strong customer captivity. Hapvida has an advantageous business model but faces growth challenges and capital constraints. Link
Links to the reports:
Brazilian Healthcare | Regulated and Consolidating Sector with Long- term Growth
Rede D'Or | Buy | An irreplicable business in the healthcare industry with still some upside
Hapvida | Hold | An efficient verticalized operator facing growth challenges and capital constraints

Banco Internacional provisions increased in the quarter even though NPLs were down from \(3.1\%\) to \(2.8\%\) due to a few specific commercial clients. The higher cost of risk does not reflect a deterioration in the overall loan portfolio, which remains sound and within historical norms. Banco Internacional net income was down \(18\%\) to \(\) 9.8\(bn due to higher provisions, while all other segments contributed positively to earnings in 2Q25 (\) 74.5bn in 2Q25 as against\) \ \(6.2bn\) net losses in 2Q24). Banco Internacional issued Chile's first AT1 bond and completed two capital increases totaling \(\) 28.5bn\(. Red Saud signed a binding agreement to acquire Nuevo Sanatorio Alemán. Currently, RedSalud has more than 40 medical and dental centers throughout Chile and nine clinics. Sanatorio Alemán Clinic in Concepción is the largest private clinic outside of Santiago and the oldest in the country. It has more than 180 beds, including adult, pediatric, and neonatalservices.

A strong quarter. ILC net earnings reached \(\) 74.5bn\(in 2Q25 as against\) \ \(6.2bn\) net losses in 2Q24, with the recognition of the liability derived from the Isapres Short Law in 2Q24 (net earnings up \(35\%\) yoy in 1H25 excluding the effect). Dividend per share was up \(33\%\) , implies \(7.9\%\) yield. The annuity market reached collections of UF35m, the highest in its history, with preference for annuities over programmed withdrawals averaging \(68\%\) during 2Q25 vs \(56\%\) in 2Q24, with Confuturo achieving \(12\%\) market share during the quarter, driving net earnings up \(105\%\) yoy to \(\) 28.9bn\(in 2Q25. Red Salud revenues increased\) 11.2\% \(in 2Q25, with EBITDA at\) \ \(27.2bn\) , up \(9.5\%\) yoy, a stable \(12.9\%\) margin. Banco Internacional's credit grew \(15.5\%\) yoy vs \(4.0\%\) for the sector, but with a lower ROE

driven by a higher cost of risk. AFP Habitat net earnings were up \(16\%\) to \(\) 46.8bn\(due to higher returns on the encaje (reserve), while AAISA net earnings were up\) 56\% \(to\) \ \(17.5bn\) also driven by a better encaje performance at AFP Habitat and co- lofondos.

Earnings level to double. ILC expects to increase its net profit level from CLP 90- 120bn in 2017- 22 (CLP 60- 80bn in 2012- 16) to CLP 150- 200bn over 2023- 2027 with \(13\% - 17\%\) ROE. Growth is expected to be primarily driven by Banco Internacional with targets to double credit by 2027/28 and reach CLP 85- 100bn net profit and a \(15\%\) ROAE, through commercial loan growth and digital to consumer. Confuto targets to reach \(\) 10- 11bn\(AUM (from\) \ \(9.4bn\) ), and CLP 80- 90bn net profit, twice the level pre- 2019, through operating leverage and portfolio diversification, further supported by the pension reform.

Valuation remains attractive. ILC's 2026E EqFCF yield is \(10\%\) with \(>7\%\) div. yield ( \(7.6\%\) av. L10Y), \(>80\%\) IPO share price. ILC trades on 6x 2026E PER and \(35\%\) discount to NAV. We estimate that ILC's current market value is implicitly assigning the group's extensive Chilean healthcare activities a negative equity value. Red Salud (healthcare) generates c \(100m\) EBITDA ( \(10\%\) 3yr CAGR).

Telesites ( \(3.7\%\) of share capital), Gruma ( \(3.1\%\) ), Vesta ( \(1.8\%\) ), Nemak ( \(1.3\%\) local), Femsa ( \(1.1\%\) ) and AMX ( \(1.1\%\) ) were the Mexican companies mostly active with buybacks YTD, with Gruma, Nemak, Inbursa, Walmex and Bimbo among the most active in the last month. We expect more to come in 2025 at AMX, Gruma, Laureate Education and Femsa.

Femsa buybacks are behind schedule but still targeting US \(900m\) in 2025 (March 25- March 26), with US \(120m\) executed in Mexico and US \(250m\) ADRs YTD. Femsa indicated earlier this year a minimum target of \(\) 5.2bn\(in dividends and buybacks is to be paid out to shareholders in 2025 and 2026. We reach\) 1x \(leverage with the minimum target, and the company has\) \ \(1.5bn\) reserved for US acquisitions, implying potential upside for another US \(1bn\) shareholder remuneration to reach the 2x leverage target.

AMX shareholders approved the dividend and buyback allocation proposed by the Board in March, comprising a dividend of \(\) 0.52\(per share, and an allocation of\) \ \(10bn\) to the buyback program for the period April 2025 - April 2026, bringing the fund to \(\) 19.6bn\(. Dividend plus buyback fund amount to\) \ \(51.5bn\) . We believe it is possible that further increases to the buyback fund may be made during the year - in 2025, \(\) 15bn\(was allocated in March and a further\) \ \(15bn\) in November.

Gruma has been one of the most active firms in Mexico with respect to buybacks, having acquired \(>15\%\) of share capital in the last 5 years. Gruma indicated that it will be increasing its buyback plan (US \(153m\) in 2024) given the current valuation, rising cash generation and low leverage ( \(1.2x vs\) 1.5x target), while maintaining its dividend policy (cUS \(100m\) ). Gruma debt was down \(10\%\) , or US \(\) 177m\(to US\) 1.6bn\(in 2024, at 1.2x EBITDA (1.5x in 2023). We believe a growth dividend policy could potentially be targeted once valuation multiples expand and the material valuation gap closes.

Alfa approved a cash dividend of US \(83m\) ( \(2\%\) yield) paid on 3rd April and a buyback plan up to a maximum of US \(290m\) ( \(7\%\) market cap). Alfa paid US \(48m\) dividends in 2024, down from US \(96m\) in 2023 as the company prioritized deleveraging and the simplification process. Sigma should generate more than US \(300m\) normalised equity free cash flow, with an EBITDA of US \(1bn\) , c8.5% EqFCF yield (ex Alpek at current levels). Sigma is implicitly trading at 5.3x 2026E EV/EBITDA vs an average 7.1x EV/EBITDA for processed/branded food companies.
Laureate has delivered consistent growth and profitability over economic cycles, with a low gearing and strong cash flow generation. We expect the company to increasingly focus on buybacks as

cash conversion rises in 2025, especially given its current market valuation, while expanding its footprint in the value segment. We expect a strong cash flow conversion of \(>US\) 200m on \(50\%\) unlevered free cash flow conversion of adj. EBITDA. The company completed a \(\) 42m\(buyback in 1Q25 and another\) \ \(29m\) in 2Q25 under the current \(\) 100m\(plan.

We are hosting a virtual group meeting with Laurence Gomes (CFO) today, Thursday, 28 August, 10.00am EST | 11.00am BRT | 15.00pm BST. C&A began operating in Brazil in 1976 and currently has more than 300 stores in 125 cities across the country. C&A has been consistently gaining share, leading 'value for money' consumer perceptions, leveraging on superior data analytics and dynamic pricing. Registration here

Energia C&A: Strong execution, more to come. The core objective of the Energia C&A strategic plan is to increase sales per sqm and productivity, through product innovation, quality improvement and category renovation, store remodeling, new format launch and expansion, and brand investment. 2024 was the first year of Energia C&A focused on strengthening the product, improving client experience, relationship and interaction. In 2025, C&A has intensified the execution of its 40 Energia C&A initiatives across the three blocks, a plan that will last until the end of 2026.

Renovation and growth. C&A has initiated a renovation plan across its store network, with 20 to 30 stores planned this year. In 2024, the company renovated 7 stores as a test, which resulted in sales per sqm at a double- digit level above average stores. C&A has intensified store reforms that will continue over coming years at a similar pace. C&A opened 5 stores this year (with another 3 planned for 2H), with above av. productivity levels, and is currently finalizing a new store format that will be launched this year. C&A will initially test 5 stores with the new format in 2H25 aiming to accelerate to 15 to 25 new stores per year from 2026. There are more than 100 locations mapped where C&A could potentially open new stores.

Momentum remains positive. There have been no signs of deceleration or deterioration in terms of traffic and conversion at C&A stores, despite stronger comps and competition (Asean platforms, H&M, Zara). C&A's products are discretionary, but with low- value ticket, and the company has been growing above peers. C&A aims to maintain competitiveness and not change its price positioning relative to Renner and Hering, with an average price \(10\%\) lower than its direct competitors. Future margin improvements are expected from dynamic pricing algorithms, logistics enhancements, and assortment optimization, reducing markdowns and boosting full- price sales.

Another strong quarter. SSS growth at \(17\%\) in 2Q25 (cons. \(13\%\) in 2Q, \(15\%\) in 1Q25), despite strong comps, with net revenues up \(12\%\) to \(R\) 2,058m on lower non apparel sales and consumer finance, and EBITDA (post IFRS- 16) up \(22\%\) yoy \(R\) 438m, and net earnings at \(R\) 124m, up \(115\%\) , \(8\%\) above. Net debt was down \(73\%\) yoy with leverage at \(0.3x\) EBITDA.

C&A ends Bradesco partnership. C&A ended the partnership with Bradesco, which started in 2009, when the bank bought Ibi and signed an agreement for the exclusive sale of its financial products in the retail network for 20 years. In 2021, C&A announced the repurchase of the right to offer financial services and products previously operated exclusively by Bradesco across its network for \(R\) 415m. C&A also sold a portfolio of Bradescard- branded credit cards for \(R\) 170m.

Management and board. A very experienced management team with well respected CEO Paulo Correa and CFO Laurence Beltrao Gomes (joined June 2023, ex Renner CFO at the time of Jose Gallo as CEO), and a team of independent board members largely represented by top managers
of leading Brazilian companies. Chairman Marcos Grasso has a long international business experience in consumer goods across Asia, Europe and Latin America.

H&M opened its first physical store in Brazil and launched online operations, and plans to open four stores in Sao Paulo state over the coming months according to H&M Brazil's country manager, in an interview to Reuters. The first Brazilian store focuses on women's fashion while the second will offer a wider assortment of products including women's, men's and children's clothing, accessories and shoes. H&M is producing shoes, beachwear and jeans in Brazil and importing the other products from different markets, including India, Bangladesh and Portugal. H&M plans to open 80 new stores globally while closing 200 stores this year in mature markets. H&M expects Brazil to become its largest market in Latin America and a key growth driver worldwide. H&M took 13 years to reach 67 stores in Mexico. Pricing is expected to be materially lower than Zara in the market but still above local department stores such as Renner and C&A.

On September 16th at 9am ET/2pm UK, we will host an expert call with economist Mr Francisco Matte to discuss Chile's political and economic outlook, ahead of the upcoming presidential elections. Mr Francisco Matte is a Strategic Advisor at The World Bank, Lecturer at the Pontificia Universidade Católica de Chile, and former Chief of Staff to the Minister of Finance. Register here.

Chile's fast approaching presidential elections (due 16th Nov) could be an inflection point for the country. Recent polls point to a lead by right- wing candidates and a new, more market friendly, administration could change the outlook for the Chilean economy. The Chilean index is up c35% YTD in US\$ terms, outperforming broader LatAm and EM indices. Join us for a call with economist Francisco Matte, Strategic Advisor at The World Bank, and former Chief of Staff to the Minister of Finance, to discuss the road to the elections and the main opportunities & challenges facing the Chilean economy under a new administration.
Date & Time: Tuesday 16th September at 09:00AM ET / 02:00PM UK / 03:00PM CET.
Registration: Click here to register. You will receive your access details via email.
There will be no replay available for this call. For Institutional Investors Only

- Polls for presidential election show a clear lead by right-wing candidates; is there any room for surprises?- What are the main opportunities & challenges for the Chilean economy?- What changes can we expect from the next administration?

Francisco Matte Risopatrón is a Lecturer (Strategy Beyond Markets) at Pontificia Universidad Católica de Chile, Board Member at Scotiabank Chile, Forum Leader at REF, and Strategic Advisor at The World Bank Group. He was previously Managing Director of International Distribution at Toesca

Asset Management, Senior Advisor (representative of Chile at the Board) at The World Bank Group (2020- 22), Senior Advisor, Executive Director's Office at The World Bank Group (2020- 22), and Chief of Staff to the Minister of Finance at the Subsecretaría del Ministerio de Hacienda (2018- 20).
We would like to thank Diego Sarmento Pereira, employee of Evalueserve Inc., for providing research support services to our preparation of this report.
For Important Disclosure information on companies recommended in this report, please visit our website at https://javatar.bluematrix.com/sellside/Disclosures.action or call 212.284.2300.
(Article 3(1)e and Article 7 of MAR) Recommendation Published

Company Specific DisclosuresAntonio Pedro Cardoso holds a long equity position in Hapvida Participações e Investimentos S.A. Antonio Pedro Cardoso holds a long equity position in Rede D'Or Sao Luiz S.A.

Buy - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of \(15\%\) or more within a 12- month period. Hold - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of plus \(15\%\) or minus \(10\%\) within a 12- month period. Underperform - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of minus \(10\%\) or less within a 12- month period. The expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) for Buy rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) or more within a 12- month period as these companies are typically more volatile than the overall stock market. For Hold rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) , the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is plus or minus \(20\%\) within a 12- month period. For Underperform rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) , the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is minus \(20\%\) or less within a 12- month period.
NR - The investment rating and price target have been temporarily suspended. Such suspensions are in compliance with applicable regulations and/or Jefferies policies.
CS - Coverage Suspended. Jefferies has suspended coverage of this company.
NC - Not covered. Jefferies does not cover this company.

Restricted - Describes issuers where, in conjunction with Jefferies engagement in certain transactions, company policy or applicable securities regulations prohibit certain types of communications, including investment recommendations.
Monitor - Describes securities whose company fundamentals and financials are being monitored, and for which no financial projections or opinions on the investment merits of the company are provided.

Jefferies methodology for assigning ratings may include the following market capitalization, maturity, growth/value, volatility and expected total return over the next 12 months. The price targets are based on several methodologies, which may include, but are not restricted to, analyses of market risk, growth rate, revenue stream, discounted cash flow (DCF), EBITDA, EPS, cash flow (CF), free cash flow (FCF), EV/EBITDA, P/E, PE/growth, P/CF, P/FCF, premium (discount)/average group EV/EBITDA, premium (discount)/average group P/E, sum of the parts, net asset value, dividend returns, and return on equity (ROE) over the next 12 months.

Jefferies Franchise PicksJefferies Franchise Picks include stock selections from among the best stock ideas from our equity analysts over a 12 month period. Stock selection is based on fundamental analysis and may take into account other factors such as analyst conviction, differentiated analysis, a favorable risk/reward ratio and investment themes that Jefferies analysts are recommending. Jefferies Franchise Picks will include only Buy rated stocks and the number can vary depending on analyst recommendations for inclusion. Stocks will be added as new opportunities arise and removed when the reason for inclusion changes, the stock has met its desired return, if it is no longer rated Buy and/or if it triggers a stop loss. Stocks having 120 day volatility in the bottom quartile of S&P stocks will continue to have a 15% stop loss, and the remainder will have a 20% stop. Franchise Picks are not intended to represent a recommended portfolio of stocks and is not sector based, but we may note where we believe a Pick falls within an investment style such as growth or value.
